results.notes:
This interesting bolete was found by Jim Barg (of NJMA) growing in a forest of black birch & beech. Hemlocks were across the stream at some distance away and thus are unlikely to be the host. The unusual habit and the unique set of morphological characters makes it tough for a generic placement. To me it gives an impression of a Retiboletus-Leccinum hybrid. This collection somewhat resembles an unusual bolete I encountered many years ago, obs 26487.

Notes by the collector (edited by me, where appropriate):
“Overall height about 4 inches, the caps were about 1-1.25” in diameter and maybe 3/8" thick at the apex. The stipes were about 3/8" in diameter and are VERY stiff and “woody”-feeling and did not break when bent lightly. The pore surface is white, non-staining. The stipe does not discolor on handling, and it seems more “deeply reticulate” than scabered. The cap is tomentose and lightly corrugated, and is non-viscid. I didn’t do any chemical tests on it, and these specimens were just too young and small to get a spore print. Overall, I’d call this one “very rugged” in terms of its makeup. The stipe is really stiff, much like Xerocomus tenax or Aureoboletus russelii."

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 29-May-2018):
> A clean and contiguous 1451 bps nrLSU sequence was obtained from this collection. The first 18 bases of the LSU region are edited out. There are 4 ambiguous characters present: 2 x “R” (A/G) and 2 x “Y” (C/T).
> A BLASTn search of the first 963 bases (through to LR5 primer) gave a single very close hit (921/925 = 99.6% similar; the 4 mismatching bases are the ambiguities in MO285593) with #AY612811/Leccinum albellum voucher TH6968 collected in NC. The next 60+ hits (only 91-94% similar) are the accessions of various members of Leccinoideae other than Leccinum: Rossbeevera (53), Leccinellum(6), Turmalinea (2) and Chalmonixia (1). Unfortunately, a subsequent GenBank search for other accessions of Leccinum/Leccinellum albellum yielded no additional sequences.
> Based on the above BLASTn profile, this collection undoubtedly belongs in Leccinoideae, possibly in Leccinellum. This collection could be a morphological outlier of L. abellum after all. According to Bessettes’ BENA (p. 238), Prof. M.E. Smith of UFL has sequenced (ITS & LSU) many examples of phenotypically variable collections of L. albellum and confirmed them to be a single taxon despite suspicions to the contrary driven by the morphology. A request to compare this sequence with those in the possession of Prof. Smith has been recently communicated via Dr. Kudzma.

results.notes: In mixed woods, primarily Eastern White Pine and Oak. Dry, white, somewhat shiny planoconvex cap measuring ~10 cm in width. Cap with off-white/pale grey pyramidal warts transitioning to small scales towards the cap edge. Odor of burnt sugar. Gills very narrowly attached, close, off-white, with many short gills. 14 cm long stem is white, with a white skirt-like ring. Stem widens to a coarsely scaly bulb, with at least two rows of scales that have minimal pinkish-brown staining. Stem tapers to a rounded point at the base of the bulb.

Two fragile fruiting bodies growing at a base of a deciduous tree (probably a hickory), with oak, beech and maple in the immediate vicinity. Pale lemon-meringue yellow caps (or light yellow-cream?) with striations of up to 0.35-0.38R and deeply buried stipes (20-30% of stipe length). With regard to the latter aspect, Rod commented: “Placement in the Penetratrices is possible. Apparently a yellow pigment did evolve within the Penetratrices. Since the Penetratrices includes mostly non-yellow species, I think the argument can be made successfully that the yellow pigment did not come from a Caesareae-like ancestor of the Vaginatae.”
The larger mushroom had a cap of 5.7×5.2 cm in width. The stipe was 13.5 cm long (the tip might have been broken off), 6 mm wide at apex, 8 mm wide at base.
The smaller mushroom had a cap of 3.5 cm in width. The stipe was 10.8 cm long, including the broken off tip with a volval sack that was recovered at the time of collection but then lost, 4 mm wide at apex, 6 mm wide at base.
The spores are globose to subglobose. I didn’t measure them yet, but taking a reticle to a few large spores at x400 without a mounting agent gave measurements of 10-12 microns.
This collection was preserved for RET.

results.notes: Growing in the duff near Lost Lake off Kebler Pass rd under spruce in mixed fir/spruce forest bordering on aspen forest along a stream. No notable odors. Yellow/brown cap, red pore surface, yellow flesh inside quickly turning blue when bruised or cut, yellow stipe overlaid with red reticulations, more red towards cap and more yellow towards the base.

Growing in chips beds around the yard after a rain. Resembles Conocybe of some type to me, but not sure. Shorter ones are more rusty, taller ones more brown. Whitish gills, pretty close together, thin pale stalks. No ring, no veil. Smaller caps more conical but larger ones flatten out. Some of these taller, browner ones were found a few feet away in a group of about 5, from the shorter rusty group of about 30 and they may actually be the same or two separate species. The lighting is different in the pics but all the stems/gills are closer to the whiter color IRL. The caps really are a bit more rust colored in some of these specimens – that’s not just the lighting.

Found on a south-facing aspect on a hill dominated by aspens growing in the soil. Osha was plentiful in this area. Smell is slightly phenolic and mild. No taste. Flesh white, cap light orangish/brown with some cap pieces curling or hanging over the margin. Stipe white with black/grey scabers. Slowly bruises grey when cut. Specimens from this same patch (within 100 feet of collection) gave me severe gastric distress when ingested two years prior to collection (2015). Intend to send sample for DNA testing.

Found in an area where mixed hardwoods were giving way to white pine. Lots of various understory plants.

Entire outer surface of mushroom is velvety and, for lack of a better word, furry. About 2 inches across and about as tall. Stipe woody. No evidence of gills or pores on underside.

Interior of mushroom is very woody towards the center. Outer 1/2 inch or so is “furry” and can easily be peeled off in sections.

An NJMA collection found at the joint Thompson Park (Jamesburg)/Helmetta Pond (Helmetta & E. Brunswick) foray.
NJMA experts tried in vane to ID this critter, but it’s likely not a Flammulaster or Cystoderma sp. Apparently growing on a conifer log in a disjunct section of the extreme northwestern outlier of the typical Pine Barrens habitat of oak-pine woods, Atlantic white cedar bog and sandy soil. The mushrooms didn’t produce a spore print, but under a microscope the spores were round and hyaline according to Nina Burghardt (the attached microscopy photos are Nina’s). Thus, the spore print is likely white or very light in color.
The specimens have been preserved.

Slowly change color in the dark gray or dark green. Collected for Igor.

Apparently there were two collections of this mushroom — one came from this location and the other was collected from Thompson Park in Monroe Township (just south of Jamesburg) that were both IDed as A. canescens (sect. Lepidella) by me. I don’t know where this one came from and what I was thinking when I identified it as canescens at the foray postmortem. Now, looking at the pix it looks like a pale A. submaculata (sect. Validae). Black fibers on the stipe is a feature consistent with the latter in my experience; canescens has white fibers that turn orange due to handling. I am afraid these were not saved.
Further input by Dr. T and others well-versed in eastern Amanitas is certainly welcome.

results.notes:
> Alright, I am going to call this bolete B. peckii because that’s the most likely ID in light of all peckii posts on MO and the general information about this species found therein and in published literature.
> This is the third time I am finding this bolete at this location (but apparently not the same spot); the previous posts are obs 73921 from 2011 and obs 104302 from 2012. Unfortunately, the first two collections were not saved.
> Unlike my benchmark peckii from Meadowoods, obs 246697, the three collections from Bernardsville always turned out to be small mushrooms with thick, pulvinate caps and short, equal or slightly ventricose stipes (about the same length as cap diameter on average) with a narrow base. It’s not clear if this is some kind of clinal variation, or stunted growth due to the ecology and/or modest levels of moisture, or that I just happen to invariably catch them at the same stage of development. The habitat is short grass & moss under old oaks.
> This particular example, collected by me on my way to the NEMF Foray in VT, had an out of round cap of 5.5 × 6.3 cm in diameter and a 5 cm long stipe, certainly not even a medium-sized fruitbody in the kingdom of boletes. The cap was 1.5 cm think in the middle; the tubes were 6 mm long in the middle; the stipe was 1.5 cm wide at the narrowest point (closer to the apex) and 1.8 cm wide near the base.
> The pictures give an accurate account of the colors. The cap was originally rose-red but turned brown from the disk toward the margins (the original color can still be seen near the margins). The stipe is a mixture of pink and pale yellow tones. The first 5 pix were taken in situ; the remaining photos were snapped the next morning after the mushroom was refrigerated overnight in a wax paper bag.
> I did not taste the flesh, nor did I run any chemical tests.

DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1 sequence of 680 bps was obtained from this material. There is a single ambiguous character present, an “R”.
> Alignment of the first 610 bases, corresponding to the region between and including EF1-983F and EF1-1567R primers, with the same region in the sequences of obs 246697 and obs 283600 shows them to be identical aside from the few ambiguities present in the three traces. The three collections appear to be conspecific.
Here is a summary of the ambiguous positions (“R” = A/G, “Y” = C/T):

…………….234…..330…..376…..410…..425….479
246697:….Y………R……….Y……….R………A………C
283600:….T………G……….Y……….R………A………Y
286124:….T………G……….C……….A………R………C

> A BLASTn search of the whole sequence gave a hit profile consistent with this species clading in Caloboletus (sorted by % identity), though the highest observed similarity doesn’t exceed 95%.
Uploaded to this observation is a GenBank-generated phylogram of the first 31 hits, with Lanmaoa pseudosensibilis accession used as an outgroup.

results.notes: A solitary specimen fruiting from leaf-litter-covered soil between a large fallen log and a small branch. When I dug it out and saw the pinched stipe I assumed it was caused by the narrow space through which it grew. However, when I later bisected this specimen I encountered nothing I have ever seen before … some sort of anomaly?? Because of the cap color, depth of the pore tubes, extensive bluing, and olive-brown spore print I am guessing it may be some sort of deformed Xerocomellus. KOH was pale yellow on cap initially and darkened to orangey-yellow within several minutes.

results.notes:
A single specimen in great shape growing on an incline near the creek in deciduous woods of oak, beech, maple, hickory and ash. This is the first time I found this bolete in WCSP since I began visiting the park in 2006.
The pictures give a fairly accurate account of the colors and morphology despite the fact that the photos were taken in natural scattered light only 45 minutes before sunset.
The pore surface, stipe surface and flesh blued when handled or cut; the bluing was very intense at the base and much less so in the cap; the upper half of stipe didn’t blue at all. The odor is fungal and earthy at the same time, fairly pleasant.

Dimensions:
> Cap = 5.5 cm wide, 1.3 cm thick in middle
> Tubes = 4 mm deep max
> Stipe = 11-12 cm long, 1.2 cm wide at apex, and 2.3 cm wide near the base

Chemical Tests:
> KOH on cap = amber brown at first, resolving orange-brown on cap
> KOH on flesh = dark orange-brown
> NH4OH on cap = at contact negative or making the cap redder (intensification of background color), then soon changing to medium brown and resolving rusty-brown to yellow-brown
> NH4OH on flesh = negative or perhaps intensifying the color to a darker shade of yellow

DNA sequencing results & discussion (last edited/updated on 26-Jan-18):
> As a foreword to the ensuing discussion, the nrLSU and TEF-1-alpha data derived from obs 243879 (bona fide “Xerocomus” sclerotiorum) and its look-alike obs 215764 point to the possibility of a ‘X. sclerotiorum group’. As noted before, the initial sequencing effort suggests that Xerocomus is hardly the right place for these taxa, and these would likely be transferred to a new or already existing genus in the subfamily Xerocomoideae in the future. The closest generic relation based on the BLASTn analysis of the LSU sequences of sclerotiorum appears to be Pulchroboletus.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 607 bps in the usual region between and including EF1-983F and EF1-1567R primers was obtained from this collection. The are no ambiguous characters. Comparison of this sequence with the TEF-1 data of obs 215764 and obs 243879/sclerotiorum showed that it’s a perfect match to the former entity.
> As I originally identified this collection in the field as “X.” sclerotiorum_, this incorrect diagnosis aptly demonstrates that separating x{GLOSSARYTERM sclerotiorum }{ sclerotiorum }x from its look-alike requires extra care. My first and only hands-on experience with this new taxon that I from now on shall refer to as “pseudosclerotiorum” dates back to fall 2015. Obviously seeing enough of both species on regular basis will eventually lead to better probabilities of field ID and shaping up of species concepts. Also, so far ecological evidence points to a difference in habitat: sclerotiorum seems to prefer the acidic sandy soil of pine-oak woods of the outer coastal plains (though obs 249019 is likely an exception in this regard), whereas my collections of “pseudosclerotiorum” came from an upland/inland hemlock-hardwood forest of southwestern MA and mixed deciduous woods of NJ, both with loam-clay type soil. Microscopy might help, too — e.g., spore size (TBD).

results.notes:
These were growing in sand on the margin of a trail leading to Chatsworth Lake. Even at maturity these were small, and by Lepidella standards these are pygmies. There was plenty of rain at FPP in the preceding week, so moisture appears not the limiting factor as far as the size is concerned.
This taxon is characterized by the small habit, a smooth, turnip-shaped bulb with a root projection, a persistent partial veil (only the apical portion survived to maturity) and pyramidal to subpyramidal brown warts on cap. The PV seems to eliminate A. subsolitaria. I couldn’t find a match on amanitaceae.org.
Unfortunately, these were not saved.
(Edited 3-Jan-18): This is likely to be the same taxon as obs 141698.

Without access to electricity, I was able to dehydrate these mushrooms by laying them out near the sunny window inside my car, placing onto aluminum foil elevated over campfire coals, and finally in my dehydrator back home. The slow dehydration process yielded decent-looking material, but it may not be DNA-worthy.
